Award.AwardTitle: METABOLOMICS: Identification of inducible bioactive plant metabolites
Award.AbstractNarration:
METABOLOMICS: Identification of Inducible Bioactive Plant Metabolites
Japan: Yutaka Okumoto, Naoki Mori, and Naoko Yoshinaga (Kyoto University)
USA: Georg Jander (Boyce Thompson Institute); Eric Schmelz and Alisa Huffaker (USDA-ARS)


Intellectual Merit: Plants produce an enormous variety of toxic and deterrent metabolites to protect themselves against pathogens and herbivores. These chemical defenses include well-studied molecules like caffeine in coffee and capsaicin in hot peppers. However, less than 10% of the metabolites in any given plant species have been identified. Many defense-related compounds are absent in non-stressed plants, but accumulate locally to very high levels following attack. The targeted identification of these small molecules, which accumulate in response to infection or herbivory, will result in the discovery previously unknown plant defenses. In the current project, defense-induced metabolites will be identified in four well-studied plant species, maize, soybean, rice and Arabidopsis. By focusing on these key species, it will be possible to make use of well-developed genetic tools and an extensive body of prior research to speed the discovery genes and pathways that are required for the synthesis of previously unknown plant metabolites. The defensive functions of the newly identified plant genes and metabolites will be confirmed with insect and pathogen bioassays.

Broader Impacts: Analysis of induced defenses in plants will lead to the identification of previously unknown molecules that have practical applications in the control of pests and diseases. A mechanistic understanding of natural plant defenses will enable targeted trait improvements that reduce energy inputs and the use of agricultural chemicals, which are required when cultivating plants for food, animal feed, and biofuel production. Interactions between American and Japanese scientists will be enhanced through this highly collaborative research project. Samples for analysis will be exchanged between research teams, scientists from the US will receive training in Japan, and undergraduate students from Japan will participate in a well-established undergraduate research program at the Boyce Thompson Institute. A new generation of plant scientists will be prepared for future careers in academia, industry, and government service.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Small molecule metabolites influence all aspects of plant biology, including vegetative growth, reproduction, and protection against countless biotic and abiotic stresses. Much of this enormous metabolic diversity is produced as layers of biochemical defenses against pathogens and herbivores. Many small molecule classes are absent in non-stressed plants but accumulate locally to very high levels following attack. However, in contrast to template-derived macromolecules such as DNA, RNA, and proteins, knowledge of the small molecule metabolome of plants is remarkably incomplete. By specifically targeting the identification of small molecules in rice and maize that accumulate after elicitation, a collaborative team of US and Japanese scientists has identified previously unknown genes and metabolites that contribute to defense against both herbivores and pathogens.

Analysis of induced-defenses in rice identified beta-tyrosine, an uncommon non-protein amino acid, as well as a tyrosine aminomutase that is involved in its biosynthesis. Growth of other plant species, in particular dicots, is inhibited by beta-tyrosine concentrations similar to those that are exuded from rice roots. Thus, beta-tyrosine may contribute to the allelopathic properties that have been observed in some rice cultivars. Other rice experiments identified natural variation in the production of naringenin, a defense-related flavonoid. Genetic mapping of this trait led to the discovery of a rice naringenin glucosyltransferase that influences the relative abundance of naringenin in different rice cultivars.

Metabolic profiling of maize subjected to aphid infestation showed progressive changes in a wide variety of genes and metabolites over time. Comparison of these data sets from aphid-infested and uninfested plants identified a terpene synthase gene, TPS2, that is strongly induced by aphid feeding. Metabolite profiling of tps2 maize mutants demonstrated that some terpenes become less abundant and others become more abundant. Reduced aphid growth on the tps2 mutants suggests that terpenes produced in a TPS2-independent manner contribute to maize resistance against aphid feeding.

In other maize experiments, metabolite profiling following attack by necrotrophic pathogens revealed a complex series of novel 9-lipoxgenase derived cyclopente(a)nones, termed death acids. With striking structural similarities to the jasmonate class of defense-related phytohormones, death acids display strong antimicrobial, insect growth inhibitory, and plant cell death inducing activities. As endogenous signals, death acids also display selective activity in plants as activators of pathogen defense-related transcription.

Results from this research have been presented in written publications and as talks at scientific meetings. Additionally project participants have made their results available to the general public in the form of outreach presentations. US and Japanese students were trained in molecular biology, genetic mapping, insect and pathogen bioassays, isolation, identification and analysis of small molecule metabolites, thereby preparing them for future careers in academia, industry, or government service.

The identification of novel, broadly active metabolites in critically important crops highlights the as yet largely untapped potential of metabolomics and its utility in uncovering novel pathways that control stress tolerance in plants. Genes, gene expression data, and metabolic structures that were identified through this project have been placed in public databases for use by scientists, plant breeders, and other interested groups.  Future efforts to improve the yield stability of maize, rice, and other major crop plants can make use of this information to increase pest and pathogen resistance.
